page.title: 2011â12 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season

revisions.rev:
{{NCAAIceHockeyTeamSeason |Image = |ImageSize = |Season = 2011â12 |Team = Boston College Eagles |Sex = men |Conference = Hockey East Association |ShortConference = Hockey East |ConferenceRank = |Poll#1 = USA Today/USA Hockey Magazine |Poll#1Rank = #3 |Poll#2 = USCHO.com/CBS College Sports |Poll#2Rank = #2 |Record = 11-5-0 |HomeRecord = 4-3-0 |RoadRecord = 5-2-0 |NeutralRecord = 2-0-0 |HeadCoach = [[Jerry York]] |AsstCoach1= Mike Cavanaugh |AsstCoach2= [[Greg Brown (ice hockey)|Greg Brown]] |AsstCoach3= Jim Logue |Captain = [[Tommy Cross]] |AltCaptain = Barry Almeida, [[Paul Carey (ice hockey)|Paul Carey]] |Arena = [[Conte Forum|Kelley Rink]] |Champion = |NCAATourney = |NCAATourneyResult = |prevseason = [[2010â11 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season|2010-11]] |headerstyle = background:#8B0000; color:#F0E68C; |labelstyle = background:#eeeeee; }} The '''2011â12 Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey team''' represents [[Boston College]] in the 2011â12 NCAA Division I men's ice hockey season. The team is coached by [[Jerry York]], '67, his eighteenth season behind the bench at Boston College. The Eagles play their home games at [[Conte Forum|Kelley Rink]] on the campus of Boston College, competing in [[Hockey East]]. Boston College enters the 2011-2012 season as reigning [[2011 Hockey East Men's Ice_Hockey Tournament|Hockey East tournament]] champions, having defeated [[Merrimack Warriors men's ice hockey|Merrimack]] 5-3 in the championship game, as well as defending [[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot]] champions, beating [[Northeastern Huskies men's ice hockey|Northeastern]] in the final 7-6 in overtime. The Eagles also won the 2010-11 Hockey East regular season championship, their first since 2004-05. In addition to the annual Beanpot Tournament in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]], the Eagles will also be participating in two other in-season tournaments, the Ice Breaker in [[Grand Forks, North Dakota|Grand Forks, ND]] and the [[Great Lakes Invitational]] in [[Detroit|Detroit, MI]]. BC won the 2011 Ice Breaker Tournament by defeating [[Michigan State Spartans men's ice hockey|Michigan State]] 5-2 in the first round, and then beating [[North Dakota Fighting Sioux men's ice hockey|North Dakota]] in the championship game, 6-2. [[Air Force Falcons men's ice hockey|Air Force]] also participated. At the end of December, BC will compete in the [[Great Lakes Invitational]] alongside [[Michigan Wolverines men's ice hockey|Michigan]], Michigan State, and [[Michigan Tech Huskies men's ice hockey|Michigan Tech]]. On November 3, it was announced that the Eagles will play [[Northeastern Huskies men's ice hockey|Northeastern]] at Fenway Park on January 14 in Hockey East play. BC will be the home team as the game was originally scheduled to be played at Kelley Rink. The contest will be a part of a double-header, with a game between [[Massachusetts Interscholastic Athletic Association|MIAA]]-rivals [[Boston College High School]] and [[Catholic Memorial School|Catholic Memorial]] slated for earlier in the day.[http://www.hockeyeastonline.com/men/pres1112/201111/nov3fen.php space BOSTON COLLEGE AND NORTHEASTERN UNIVERSITY MEN'S HOCKEY TEAMS SET TO PLAY AT FENWAY PARK] ==Offseason== March 27, 2011: Junior forward [[Cam Atkinson]] signed with the [[Columbus Blue Jackets]], forgoing his senior season. [http://bceagles.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/032711aaa.html Atkinson To Forgo Senior Season To Pursue Pro Career] March 30, 2011: Junior forward Jimmy Hayes signed with the [[Chicago Blackhawks]], also forgoing his senior season. [http://bceagles.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/033011aag.html Hayes To Forgo Senior Season To Pursue Pro Career] April 11, 2011: Sophomores [[Brian Dumoulin]] and [[Chris Kreider]] announced that they would return to Boston College for the 2011-12 season. [http://bceagles.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/041111aaa.html Dumoulin, Kreider To Return To BC For 2011-12 Season] April 13, 2011: Sophomore defenseman [[Philip Samuelsson]] decided to forgo his final two seasons with Boston College to pursue a pro career in the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] organization. [http://bceagles.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/041311aaa.html Samuelsson To Forgo Final Two Seasons To Pursue Pro Career]
Also, sophomore forward Chris Kreider was selected to the [[United States men's national ice hockey team|United States national team]] that competed at the [[2011 IIHF World Championship]] in [[Slovakia]].[http://bceagles.cstv.com/sports/m-hockey/spec-rel/041311aac.html Kreider Named To U.S. National Team] ==Recruiting== Boston College adds nine freshmen for the 2011-2012 season: two goaltenders in Brian Billet and Brad Barone, both alumni of the [[Eastern Junior Hockey League|EJHL]]; two recruits from Canada in Mark Begert, a defenseman, and Destry Straight, a forward, who were teammates with the [[Coquitlam Express]] of the [[British Columbia Junior Hockey League|BCHL]]; forward Danny Linell, a [[Long Island]] native and 2011-12 recipient of the Hugh and Doris MacIsaac Family Scholarship Fund; forward Johnny Gaudreau, a fourth round pick of the [[Calgary Flames]] in the [[2011 NHL Entry Draft]] who was previously committed to play at [[Northeastern University|Northeastern]]; [[Hingham, MA|Hingham]]-native Cam Spiro, who was also an All-American lacrosse player at [[Tabor Academy]]; forward Michael Sit, a [[Minnesota]] native who joins the Eagles from powerhouse [[Edina High School|Edina]]; and forward Quinn Smith, who played for the [[Youngstown Phantoms]] in the [[United States Hockey League|USHL]]. {|class="wikitable" width="60%" |- Beanpot = 60th Annual [[Beanpot (ice hockey)|Beanpot Tournament]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston, MA]] *On October 8, Boston College won its third Ice Breaker title by defeating [[North Dakota Fighting Sioux men's ice hockey|North Dakota]] 6-2 in [[Grand Forks, North Dakota|Grand Forks, ND]]. Junior [[Chris Kreider]] was named tournament MVP and Parker Milner, Bill Arnold, Kreider, [[Tommy Cross]] and Patch Alber earned all-tournament honors. [http://hockeyeastonline.com/men/pres1112/201110/oct10wr.php Week of October 10, 2011], [http://www.hockeyeastonline.com/men/pres1112/201110/oct31wr.php Week of October 31, 2011] ==External links== *[http://bceagles.collegesports.com/sports/m-hockey/bc-m-hockey-body.html BC Men's Hockey Home Page] *[http://www.uscho.com/m/boston-college-eagles/mens-college-hockey/team,bc.html BC Men's Hockey Page on USCHO] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Boston College}} {{Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey season, 2011â12}} [[Category:Boston College Eagles men's ice hockey seasons]] [[Category:2011â12 NCAA Division I men's ice hockey season]]
